conclusion: Identify the objects and their corresponding shadows: A = short flat cake, B = tall nail/pin, C = roll of bandage, D = thin ring lying almost flat.
Bandage-roll shadow is on its left, nail shadow points slightly forward, and shadows are short.
The lamp must be upper-front-right of the scene and fairly high based on shadow positions.
The lamp is moved to the back-right, meaning it stays to the right, goes behind the objects, and height remains roughly the same.
The light vector turns approximately 180° around the objects in the front-back direction but stays on the right, resulting in shadows running toward front-left.
Shadow A (cake) will slide slightly to the front-left of the cake with a small offset due to its low height.
Shadow B (nail) will swing around by approximately 180° horizontally, point strongly to the front-left, and become much longer due to the lamp being behind.
Shadow C (bandage roll) will move to the roll’s front-left corner, flip sides, and be longer than A’s but shorter than B’s.
Shadow D (ring) will shift slightly to the front-left with negligible offset and retain its size and shape.
Height of objects affects shadow length: taller objects have longer shadows when the lamp moves lower vertically.
Shadow B experiences the largest relative growth, becoming a long diagonal streak.
Shadow C grows moderately, forming an oval/rectangle roughly one bandage-roll length in the front-left direction.
Shadow A grows slightly, remaining a small circular/oval patch.
Shadow D experiences virtually no growth, remaining a thin outline.

Final answer: Shadows migrate to the front-left of their objects. A moves slightly and remains small; B swings far, points front-left, and lengthens significantly; C moves to the roll’s front-left and lengthens moderately; D shifts slightly front-left and retains its size and shape.
